issue.title: [BUG] AssertionError: Multiple .egg-info directories found

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

setuptools-68.2.2-py3-none-any.whl

### Python version

PyPy 7.3.13 with Python (3.9.18)

### OS

ubuntu-22.04

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

Building and installing [bitstruct](https://github.com/eerimoq/bitstruct) under PyPy fails with `AssertionError: Multiple .egg-info directories found`. It works fine under CPython.

### Expected behavior

The package should be installed without issues.

### How to Reproduce

1. Get [PyPy 3.9](https://www.pypy.org/download.html)
3. git clone https://github.com/eerimoq/bitstruct.git
4. cd ./bitstruct
5. pip install .

### Output

```console
Successfully installed setuptools-68.2.2
  Installing build dependencies: finished with status 'done'
  Getting requirements to build wheel: started
  Running command Getting requirements to build wheel
  Getting requirements to build wheel: finished with status 'done'
  Installing backend dependencies: started
  Running command pip subprocess to install backend dependencies
  Using pip 23.3.1 from /opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip (python 3.9)
  /opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip/_vendor/certifi/cacert.pem None
  Collecting wheel
    Obtaining dependency information for wheel from https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/b8/8b/312[73](https://github.com/zariiii9003/bitstruct/actions/runs/6657684616/job/18092909478#step:4:74)bf66016be6ad22bb7345c37ff350276cfd46e389a0c2ac5da9d9073/wheel-0.41.2-py3-none-any.whl.metadata
  /opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip/_vendor/certifi/cacert.pem None
    Downloading wheel-0.41.2-py3-none-any.whl.metadata (2.2 kB)
  Downloading wheel-0.41.2-py3-none-any.whl (64 kB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 64.8/64.8 kB 2.9 MB/s eta 0:00:00
  Installing collected packages: wheel
    Creating /tmp/pip-build-env-z0j8mivu/normal/bin
    changing mode of /tmp/pip-build-env-z0j8mivu/normal/bin/wheel to [75](https://github.com/zariiii9003/bitstruct/actions/runs/6657684616/job/18092909478#step:4:76)5
  Successfully installed wheel-0.41.2
  Installing backend dependencies: finished with status 'done'
  Created temporary directory: /tmp/pip-modern-metadata-l20yvtoh
  Preparing metadata (pyproject.toml): started
  Running command Preparing metadata (pyproject.toml)
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py", line 353, in <module>
      main()
    File "/opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py", line 335, in main
      json_out['return_val'] = hook(**hook_input['kwargs'])
    File "/opt/hostedtoolcache/PyPy/3.9.18/x64/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py", line 149, in prepare_metadata_for_build_wheel
      return hook(metadata_directory, config_settings)
    File "/tmp/pip-build-env-z0j8mivu/overlay/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/setuptools/build_meta.py", line 398, in prepare_metadata_for_build_wheel
      self._bubble_up_info_directory(metadata_directory, ".egg-info")
    File "/tmp/pip-build-env-z0j8mivu/overlay/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/setuptools/build_meta.py", line 367, in _bubble_up_info_directory
      info_dir = self._find_info_directory(metadata_directory, suffix)
    File "/tmp/pip-build-env-z0j8mivu/overlay/lib/pypy3.9/site-packages/setuptools/build_meta.py", line 3[78](https://github.com/zariiii9003/bitstruct/actions/runs/6657684616/job/18092909478#step:4:79), in _find_info_directory
      assert len(candidates) == 1, f"Multiple {suffix} directories found"
  AssertionError: Multiple .egg-info directories found
  error: subprocess-exited-with-error
```

[Here you can see the output of pip with high verbosity.](https://github.com/zariiii9003/bitstruct/actions/runs/6657684616/job/18092909478)

review.body: Thank you very much @hroncok. Probably we can add this to the next release of setuptools (which I am planning for some time around the beginning of the month, but may change if Jason has a different idea).

issue.title: [Docs]

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### Summary

Was reading the documentation for setuptools v68.2.2 and have problems understanding the meaning of the 'license' meta-data field, see https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/stable/deprecated/distutils/setupscript.html#additional-meta-data

> The license field is a text indicating the license covering the package where the license is not a selection from the “License” Trove classifiers.

For me it is unclear, what this "where … is not a selection from" means:
- Is this fields only to be set if the license is not one of those available as “License” Trove classifier?
- Is the field allowed to be set if the license is not one of those available as “License” Trove classifier?
- Does this field take precedence over any “License” Trove classifier listed in the package? Or the other way round?
- 

### OS / Environment

n/a

### Additional Information

Proposal for rewording:

The license field is a text indicating the license covering the package if the license of the package is available as the “License” Trove classifiers.
If the license is available as “License” Trove classifier, please use that one and leave the `license` field away.
If the license is not available as “License” Trove classifier, please set “License” Trove classifier to `License :: Other/Proprietary License` and briefly state the license here.

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow the PSF Code of Conduct

comment.body:
Hi @htgoebel, to be honest the page you are referring to is part of the `distutils` documentation that `setuptools` simply carries over for archival/consultation, but otherwise overwrites with more "up-to-date" docs outside of the `.../deprecated/...` URL.

The [newer docs](https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/stable/references/keywords.html) say:
> - `license`: A string specifying the license of the package.
> - `license_files`: A list of glob patterns for license related files that should be included. If neither license_file nor license_files is specified, this option defaults to `LICEN[CS]E*`, `COPYING*`, `NOTICE*`, and `AUTHORS*`.

So yes, you kind of can put anything you want there.

---

The [Core Metadata](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/core-metadata/#license) specification (which is the thing produced with the information you give to setuptools) does define `License` as:

> Text indicating the license covering the distribution where the license is not a selection from the “License” Trove classifiers. See [“Classifier”](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/core-metadata/#metadata-classifier) below. This field may also be used to specify a particular version of a license which is named via the Classifier field, or to indicate a variation or exception to such a license.
> 
> Examples:
>
> ```
> License: This software may only be obtained by sending the
>          author a postcard, and then the user promises not
>          to redistribute it.
> ```
>
> ```
> License: GPL version 3, excluding DRM provisions
> ```

However, there is a strong push in the community to use [SPDX license identifiers](https://spdx.org/licenses/) and get rid of the license classifiers (see ***pending*** [PEP 639](https://peps.python.org/pep-0639/) draft). Personally, my current approach is to always use `license_files` and then add an SPDX id to `license`, and basically ignore the classifiers because I don't think they contribute much, but each individual decides what works best for them 😝.

---

Regarding your suggestions, please note that we normally don't modify anything in the `distutils` namespace in this project, they are simply archived for historical reasons. But if you want to modify `distutils` docs the best would be opening an issue/discussion in the `pypa/distutils` repository and check with the maintainers there if the change is welcome there.

Now if you want to modify the documentation pages referring to `setuptools` itself, please feel free to open a PR. In my personal opinion, I prefer to wait until PEP 639 is finally approved before providing official advice (since it may change until it reaches a "ready" state).

For now the field is kind of a "free form" string that users can decide how to best fit their needs.

issue.body:
### Summary

Was reading the documentation for setuptools v68.2.2 and have problems understanding the meaning of the 'license' meta-data field.

> The license field is a text indicating the license covering the package where the license is not a selection from the “License” Trove classifiers.

For me it is unclear, what this "where … is not a selection from" means:
- Is this fields only to be set if the license is not one of those available as “License” Trove classifier?
- Is the field allowed to be set if the license is not one of those available as “License” Trove classifier?
- Does this field take precedence over any “License” Trove classifier listed in the package? Or the other way round?
- 

### OS / Environment

n/a

### Additional Information

Proposal for rewording:

The license field is a text indicating the license covering the package if the license of the package is available as the “License” Trove classifiers.
If the license is available as “License” Trove classifier, please use that one and leave the `license` field away.
If the license is not available as “License” Trove classifier, please set “License” Trove classifier to `License :: Other/Proprietary License` and briefly state the license here.

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow the PSF Code of Conduct

issue.title: [BUG] setuptools.depends:get_module_constant returns None on Python 3.13.0a1
issue.body:
### setuptools version

65.6.3.post20230109

### Python version

3.13.0a1

### OS

Fedora Linux

### Additional environment information

This happens with later versions as well, but I reproduced from the main branch @ 2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082

### Description

The `get_module_constant` function from `setuptools.depends` returns `None` instead of the actual constant value on Python 3.13.0a1. This works fine on Python 3.12.0.

### Expected behavior

The function should work the same on Python 3.12 and 3.13.

### How to Reproduce

1. Create a simple Python file with a constant in it.
2. Run `setuptools.depends:get_module_constant` to retrieve it.

### Output

```console
$ cat foobar.py 
__version__ = "1"

$ venv3.12/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
1

$ venv3.13/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
None
```

comment.body:
This should use [`dis.opmap`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/dis.html#dis.opmap) rather than hardcoding the numeric values.
However, there is also no guarantee that e.g. `LOAD_CONST` will continue to be used for all loads of a constant -- CPython could, for example, add `LOAD_CONST_STR` that load string constants. So even `dis.opmap` isn't future-proof.

issue.title: [BUG] [easy_install] bug on checking the path of the distribution location

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

setuptools===68.2.2

### Python version

Python 3.10

### OS

Windows 11

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

I can see if the package source path is already added to the PYTHONPATH then it's failing add the package source directory to the easy-install.pth when I run the "pip install -e ."
 
easy_install.py
```python
    def add(self, dist):
        """Add `dist` to the distribution map"""
        new_path = dist.location not in self.paths and (
            dist.location not in self.sitedirs
            or
            # account for '.' being in PYTHONPATH
            dist.location == os.getcwd()
        )
        if new_path:
            self.paths.append(dist.location)
            self.dirty = True
        super().add(dist)
```
In def add(self, dist) function in easy_install.py
> dist.location == os.getcwd()

This code will return False, because the dist.location is already normcased during finalize_options in develop.py
> target =  _path.normpath(self.egg_base)

This target is passed as the location in Distribution
>        # Make a distribution for the package's source
>        self.dist = pkg_resources.Distribution(
>            target,
>            pkg_resources.PathMetadata(target, os.path.abspath(ei.egg_info)),
>            project_name=ei.egg_name,
>        )

For example, if the dist.location and os.getcwd() is 
dist.location = 'c:\users\abc\work\helloworld'  
os.getcwd() = 'C:\Users\abc\work\helloworld'

The result is False, even though they are pointing same path.

it  should be updated to
> dist.location == os.path.normcase(os.getcwd()) 

easy_install.py
```python
    def add(self, dist):
        """Add `dist` to the distribution map"""
        new_path = dist.location not in self.paths and (
            dist.location not in self.sitedirs
            or
            # account for '.' being in PYTHONPATH
            # dist.location is _path.nomcased but the os.getcwd() is not
            dist.location == os.path.normcase(os.getcwd())
        )
        if new_path:
            self.paths.append(dist.location)
            self.dirty = True
        super().add(dist)
```


### Expected behavior

The path of source code should be added to the easy-install.pth file when it's installed as editable.

### How to Reproduce

Add "." (current path) to the PYTHONPATH then run the "pip install -e ." 

### Output

If the easy-install.pth is not exist. it will not dump any error.
But if there is easy-install.pth file exist, it will show this erro.

```output
      File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\setuptools\command\easy_install.py", line 1690, in save
        self.dirty |= last_dirty or self.paths != self._init_paths
    TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for |=: 'list' and 'bool'
```

comment.body:
Hi @spxd, I can see that you already did a very in-depth investigation. Thank you very much for that. Would you like to provide a PR as well?

> I can see if the package source path is already added to the PYTHONPATH then it's failing add the package source directory to the easy-install.pth when I run the "pip install -e ."

Note however that the latest versions of `pip` may not use the `develop` command, but instead rely on PEP 660.
It was planned that pip 23.1+ would already adopt this behaviour by default, but that got postponed for a while.

If you want to opt-in for the "new behaviour" you can use `pip install --use-pep517 -e .`

issue.title: [BUG] setuptools.depends:get_module_constant returns None on Python 3.13.0a1

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

65.6.3.post20230109

### Python version

3.13.0a1

### OS

Fedora Linux

### Additional environment information

This happens with later versions as well, but I reproduced from the main branch @ 2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082

### Description

The `get_module_constant` function from `setuptools.depends` returns `None` instead of the actual constant value on Python 3.13.0a1. This works fine on Python 3.12.0.

### Expected behavior

The function should work the same on Python 3.12 and 3.13.

### How to Reproduce

1. Create a simple Python file with a constant in it.
2. Run `setuptools.depends:get_module_constant` to retrieve it.

### Output

```console
$ cat foobar.py 
__version__ = "1"

$ venv3.12/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
1

$ venv3.13/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
None
```

comment.body:
By debugging the setuptools code, I figured out the bytecode numbers must have changed:

```
$ venv3.13/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
RESUME 149
LOAD_CONST 83
STORE_NAME 114
RETURN_CONST 103
None
```

```
$ venv3.12/bin/python -c 'import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__); from setuptools.depends import get_module_constant; print(get_module_constant("foobar", "__version__"))'
65.6.3.post20230109
RESUME 151
LOAD_CONST 100
STORE_NAME 90
1
```

That's from https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082/setuptools/depends.py#L145-L147

issue.title: [BUG] `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` - AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

68.2.2

### Python version

3.11.2

### OS

Raspberry Pi OS (Bookworm)

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

It looks like `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` attempts to call `self.parse()` in `__init__` if a version string is supplied.

Since the `parse` method is not defined, it will:

1. Raise `AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'`
2. Never emit the deprecation warning

Additionally calling `Version` with no arguments triggers a  `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded` exception, since the DeprecationWarning attempts to get a string representation of the class which causes a recursion since `__repr__` - in lieu of a `__str__` method - calls itself.

It's self evident from the source that something is wrong here- https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082/setuptools/_distutils/version.py#L45-L93

`Version` does not supply `parse` or `__str__` via a parent class or otherwise.

### Expected behavior

I know the answer is "don't use this, it's deprecated" but should `Version` not still work with a:

```
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
```

And no errors.

Fail with an error?

Not exist at all?

### How to Reproduce

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version("1.6.3")
```

Or

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version()
```

### Output

```console
>>> from setuptools._distutils import version
>>> version.Version("1.6.3")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 54, in __init__
    self.parse(vstring)
    ^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'
```

```console
>>> version.Version()
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  [Previous line repeated 492 more times]
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

issue.title: [BUG] `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` - AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

68.2.2

### Python version

3.11.2

### OS

Raspberry Pi OS (Bookworm)

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

It looks like `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` attempts to call `self.parse()` in `__init__` if a version string is supplied.

Since the `parse` method is not defined, it will:

1. Raise `AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'`
2. Never emit the deprecation warning

Additionally calling `Version` with no arguments triggers a  `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded` exception, since the DeprecationWarning attempts to get a string representation of the class which causes a recursion since `__repr__` - in lieu of a `__str__` method - calls itself.

It's self evident from the source that something is wrong here- https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082/setuptools/_distutils/version.py#L45-L93

`Version` does not supply `parse` or `__str__` via a parent class or otherwise.

### Expected behavior

I know the answer is "don't use this, it's deprecated" but should `Version` not still work with a:

```
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
```

And no errors.

Fail with an error?

Not exist at all?

### How to Reproduce

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version("1.6.3")
```

Or

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version()
```

### Output

```console
>>> from setuptools._distutils import version
>>> version.Version("1.6.3")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 54, in __init__
    self.parse(vstring)
    ^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'
```

```console
>>> version.Version()
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  [Previous line repeated 492 more times]
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

comment.body:
Agreed- if it's deprecated then there's no reason to change it. `LooseVersion` and `StrictVersion` both work as expected.

I was operating on a misunderstanding while trying to add version parsing in a legacy setup.py. It's been a long day. Sorry.

issue.title: [BUG] `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` - AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

68.2.2

### Python version

3.11.2

### OS

Raspberry Pi OS (Bookworm)

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

It looks like `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` attempts to call `self.parse()` in `__init__` if a version string is supplied.

Since the `parse` method is not defined, it will:

1. Raise `AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'`
2. Never emit the deprecation warning

Additionally calling `Version` with no arguments triggers a  `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded` exception, since the DeprecationWarning attempts to get a string representation of the class which causes a recursion since `__repr__` - in lieu of a `__str__` method - calls itself.

It's self evident from the source that something is wrong here- https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082/setuptools/_distutils/version.py#L45-L93

`Version` does not supply `parse` or `__str__` via a parent class or otherwise.

### Expected behavior

I know the answer is "don't use this, it's deprecated" but should `Version` not still work with a:

```
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
```

And no errors.

Fail with an error?

Not exist at all?

### How to Reproduce

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version("1.6.3")
```

Or

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version()
```

### Output

```console
>>> from setuptools._distutils import version
>>> version.Version("1.6.3")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 54, in __init__
    self.parse(vstring)
    ^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'
```

```console
>>> version.Version()
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  [Previous line repeated 492 more times]
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

comment.body:
I think we should close this for now, having in mind that the class is abstract.

If anyone would like to change that, the best way would be to discuss the viability  and provide a follow-up PR in the `pypa/distutils` repository.

issue.title: [BUG] `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` - AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be evaluated for severity and status.

issue.body:
### setuptools version

68.2.2

### Python version

3.11.2

### OS

Raspberry Pi OS (Bookworm)

### Additional environment information

_No response_

### Description

It looks like `setuptools._distutils.version.Version` attempts to call `self.parse()` in `__init__` if a version string is supplied.

Since the `parse` method is not defined, it will:

1. Raise `AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'`
2. Never emit the deprecation warning

Additionally calling `Version` with no arguments triggers a  `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded` exception, since the DeprecationWarning attempts to get a string representation of the class which causes a recursion since `__repr__` - in lieu of a `__str__` method - calls itself.

It's self evident from the source that something is wrong here- https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/2384d915088b960999ca74fb81ce70bffd17b082/setuptools/_distutils/version.py#L45-L93

`Version` does not supply `parse` or `__str__` via a parent class or otherwise.

### Expected behavior

I know the answer is "don't use this, it's deprecated" but should `Version` not still work with a:

```
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
```

And no errors.

Fail with an error?

Not exist at all?

### How to Reproduce

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version("1.6.3")
```

Or

```python
from setuptools._distutils import version
version.Version()
```

### Output

```console
>>> from setuptools._distutils import version
>>> version.Version("1.6.3")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 54, in __init__
    self.parse(vstring)
    ^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'Version' object has no attribute 'parse'
```

```console
>>> version.Version()
<stdin>:1: DeprecationWarning: distutils Version classes are deprecated. Use packaging.version instead.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sandiska1/.virtualenvs/pimoroni/lib/python3.11/site-packages/setuptools/_distutils/version.py", line 63, in __repr__
    return "{} ('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, str(self))
                                                       ^^^^^^^^^
  [Previous line repeated 492 more times]
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

comment.body:
Hi, can you reproduce this without importing from `setuptools._distutils`?

Imports from `setuptools._distutils` are not supported, and are know to cause problems.

The fact that there is a `_distutils` inside `setuptools` is a private implementation detail. The import is not supposed to work without passing through the `MetaPathFinder`. If you want to use `distutils` please import using the `distutils` name directly...

Please also note that the docstring for the class says that `distutils.version.Version` is an abstract class, so it will not work if used without the proper subclassing.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,8 @@
-from distutils.dep_util import newer_group
+from distutils.dep_util import (
+    newer as newer,
+    newer_pairwise as newer_pairwise,
+    newer_group as newer_group,
+)
comment.body:
This could also be written as
```suggestion
from distutils.dep_util import *
```

pull_request.title: Re-export `distutils.dep_util` through `setuptools.dep_util`
pull_request.body:
<!-- First time contributors: Take a moment to review https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/development/developer-guide.html! -->
<!-- Remove sections if not applicable -->

## Summary of changes

Re-export `distutils.dep_util` through `setuptools.dep_util`

I'm looking into progressively migrating `distutil` usage in pywin32 (https://github.com/mhammond/pywin32/issues/2119), where `distutils.dep_util.newer` and `distutils.dep_util.newer_group` are used.

Migration guides (https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/deprecated/distutils-legacy.html and https://peps.python.org/pep-0632/#migration-advice) don't mention `distutils.dep_util`.

`setuptools.dep_util` already exists. It seems sensible to re-export the rest of `distutils.dep_util` as part of `setuptool`'s API.

### Pull Request Checklist
- [ ] Changes have tests
- [x] News fragment added in [`newsfragments/`].
  _(See [documentation][PR docs] for details)_


[`newsfragments/`]: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/tree/master/newsfragments
[PR docs]:
https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/development/developer-guide.html#making-a-pull-request

Do you have an idea when this will be released?

pull_request.title: Fix all mypy issues
pull_request.body:
<!-- First time contributors: Take a moment to review https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/development/developer-guide.html! -->
<!-- Remove sections if not applicable -->

## Summary of changes

Progress towards #2345 
I'm not familiar with tox or this project's CI setup, could I get a hand to ensure that mypy errors are blocking on the CI now that they're all fixed with base configuration?

Changes:
- Fixed all mypy issues with base configurations
- Use `pyproject.toml` instead of `mypy.ini` to merge tooling configurations (it also makes [exclude](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/config_file.html#confval-exclude) configuration a bit cleaner as it supports arrays in `.toml` format)
  - If you still prefer having a standalone `mypy.ini`, I'll move it back and adapt the `exclude` config. 
- Added comments to explain configuration decisions
- Explicitly target oldest supported Python version
- Excluded vendored modules, the build folder and a file that was causing "duplicate module name" issues with mypy
- Bumped `pytest-mypy` to its latest version

`mypy . --python-version=3.8` results:
![image](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/assets/1350584/1f464fe8-eb7f-4816-b2cd-6d390d3a2b37)

The additional stubs (`.pyi`) files might be undesirable atm for the scope of this PR. If so, I'll remove them and suppress/ignore relevant errors in mypy instead and will tackle that specific issue in a different PR.

### Pull Request Checklist
- [ ] Changes have tests (see my comment/question about enforcing this in the CI)
- [x] News fragment added in [`newsfragments/`]. (should not affect the end user yet)
  _(See [documentation][PR docs] for details)_


[`newsfragments/`]: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/tree/master/newsfragments
[PR docs]:
https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/development/developer-guide.html#making-a-pull-request

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -27,7 +28,12 @@
 
 pytestmark = pytest.mark.integration
 
-(LATEST,) = Enum("v", "LATEST")
+
+class v(Enum):
+    LATEST = 1
+
+
+(LATEST,) = v
comment.body:
The exact error is: `"Enum" object is not iterable`

And here's why there has been no effort in supporting this form in mypy: https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/8009#issuecomment-558335186
Might be worth opening an issue for this specific feature anyway

pyright does seem to understand it just right.
